conversation_id: "686fa7bf-3af0-8011-b3c7-5d7bd6237a3e" title: "Amazon Onboarding Frustrations" accounts: ["Account2_exports"] models: [] tags: [] message_count: 39

Amazon Onboarding Frustrations

user

system

2025-07-10T11:45:01.174000Z user

Is Amazon always so terrible at communicating?

I opted instead of going in person to simply use my hotspot for a moment to try once again contacting my manager and onboarding support leaving my phone number. I managed to change my login and get logged into the Embark portal. But I'm just curious if they're always so .... strange

Nobody has contacted me - just automated messages about onboarding tasks and this and that shit - all of which are now completed.

2025-07-10T11:45:03.593991Z assistant

I hear you. This is actually extremely common for Amazonespecially for warehouse, delivery, and technician roles (including mechatronics/robotics techs).

Heres the blunt truth: Amazons hiring and onboarding communication is notoriously fragmented and impersonal. They rely heavily on automated systems, email templates, and self-service onboarding portals like Embark. For most roles, the actual human contact is minimal until you physically show up on Day 1.

Why is it like this?

1 Scale
Amazon hires hundreds of thousands of people each year. Automation is the only way they manage the volume.

2 Distributed HR
They dont have a dedicated local HR person for every new hire. Instead, they use regional hiring hubs.

3 Cost Efficiency
Every human phone call costs money. Automation is cheaper.

4 Assumed Initiative
Their model expects you to:

  • Check your email and Embark portal constantly
  • Complete tasks on your own
  • Show up when and where they told you, without much hand-holding

What usually happens next:
You finish all your Embark tasks.
You dont get any personal email or call.
You just show up on the first day they assigned.
Then youll meet a real human manager or HR person in person.

Bottom line:
Amazon's approach isnt personal, but its (usually) functional. The expectation is: if you did the onboarding steps, youre good to go, and they'll see you at your start date.

My suggestion for you:

Keep checking your Embark portal thats the single source of truth.
Watch your email (including spam/junk).
Dont panic if you dont hear back from a humanits normal.
If you want, try again to call or emailbut dont be surprised if they dont answer quickly.

If you want, tell me what role you were hired for and what your portal says your start date is. I can help you figure out what you can expect next or even draft you a short, professional follow-up email to send them if you want to keep pushing.

Youre not alone in this experienceit really is always this strange, for a lot of people.

2025-07-10T11:45:15.338062Z assistant

2025-07-10T11:45:51.180000Z user

I don't have a way to continuously check that email - and I don't have a number to call...

Should I just go there physically?

2025-07-10T11:45:53.361974Z assistant

Excellentlets get real about this.

Short answer:
If you can get there in personyes, that is usually the fastest way to get clarity.

Longer answer:
Amazon expects people to rely on the portal and email, but theyre notorious for giving incomplete info or no personal follow-up. Showing up at the site in person is how thousands of Amazon hires have solved this exact problem.

Youre actually doing the smart thing by thinking about going in person.

Heres how to approach it:

1 Before you go

  • Make sure you know which facility youre supposed to report to (Embark or emails usually say).
  • Bring any ID or documents they might want.
  • If possible, screenshot or write down anything from the Embark portal that says you were hired, your start date, or onboarding status (even if you had to log in from a hotspot once).

2 When you get there

  • Go to security or the front desk and say:

Confirm your start date.
Send you to HR or your manager.
Or explain if anything else is missing.

  • Amazon sites are used to this. They have a process for walk-ins who are in onboarding limbo.
